item.title: Considerations about Death
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description:
Generally the topic of death is largely invisible in our society. Dead people are transported off of hospitals only during the night, millions are spend on artificial teeth every year and old people take medication during family gatherings to temporarily overshadow the effect of “old people diseases” like Alzheimer's. Decay in general pains us and is masked out.

But even though we try to avoid death itself and we generally don't wish it on anybody, which useful things can we draw from considering death?

item.title: healing
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: These “bits” I share here are short pieces of information that came up while being in meditative states. While in strictly logical terms they might not make sense to you, for fellow meditators the probably mean alot. Either way, you might still find some of them to be inspiring. At a certain height of experience, let the feeling of openness and enough-ness echo and vibrate through your being, especially the stomach.

item.title: Contributing to Society, Part 1: Money
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: It has been troubling me what constitutes making a contribution to society. Is it going to work? Is it making art? Is it being a helpful neighbor? Since I'm benefiting from a working society, I sure would want to secure that it keeps thriving, possibly even help elevating it to the next level.

item.title: Motivational Tides
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: I find motivation at work to adhere to certain laws. How can motivation be fostered and how is it drowned? A quick read on the aspect of variance and choice.

item.title: Our thoughts are not free
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: Opposite to the traditional German folk song “Die Gedanken sind frei” (All thoughts are free) I claim otherwise. I will explain this in strictly logical terms, giving examples and scientific evidence, while the insight itself only came after long meditation.

item.title: Your body as a kingdom
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: A blog post based on a shower thought.

item.title: Inspiring Figures
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: For many years now I really enjoy following inspirational figures of our time. In this post I'd like take the time to highlight my personal favorites and show how they relate to each other.

item.title: Notes of a Meditator, Part I
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: Meditation is a pretty cool hobby, which oftentimes happens alone. In this post I'd like to share how I go about my daily practices as a meditator.

item.title: On Growing in a Company
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: A quick read on the impact of company style on personal growth.

item.title: lostinthought
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: These “bits” I share here are short pieces of information that came up while being in meditative states. While in strictly logical terms they might not make sense to you, for fellow meditators the probably mean alot. Either way, you might still find some of them to be inspiring. At their core, human beings just want to be seen for what they are. So when you decide to drop your assumptions and pay absolute attention, you eyes start glowing and they will pay you back with everything they have: what they are.

item.title: meditation
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: These “bits” I share here are short pieces of information that came up while being in meditative states. While in strictly logical terms they might not make sense to you, for fellow meditators the probably mean alot. Either way, you might still find some of them to be inspiring. Dont give your own genious such easy tasks all the time. Let it fly, let it rip - let it do its playful dance (in #meditation).

item.title: nofilter
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: These “bits” I share here are short pieces of information that came up while being in meditative states. While in strictly logical terms they might not make sense to you, for fellow meditators the probably mean alot. Either way, you might still find some of them to be inspiring. Nothing in our environment holds us back. We just live blindly. #nofilter #spirituality Dein Körper ist ein #Tempel. Du musst ihn putzen, waschen, verteidigen, bewachen, pflegen, und dich in ihm zu neuen #Höhen aufschwingen.

item.title: spirituality
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: These “bits” I share here are short pieces of information that came up while being in meditative states. While in strictly logical terms they might not make sense to you, for fellow meditators the probably mean alot. Either way, you might still find some of them to be inspiring. When a spiritual person is not enlightened, it means clarity and intention never came together. #spirituality #theorizing When we neglect “our dark side”, or simply certain aspects of ourselves, we play while missing certain members of our team.

While in strictly logical terms they might not make sense to you, for fellow meditators the probably mean alot. Either way, you might still find some of them to be inspiring. When a spiritual person is not enlightened, it means clarity and intention never came together. #spirituality #theorizing When we neglect “our dark side”, or simply certain aspects of ourselves, we play while missing certain members of our team.

item.title: School and Agile
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: A quick read on 3 major differences I found between work in school and work in adult life, specifically in my context of working agile.

item.title: Becoming Greener, Episode I
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: Some notes on recent steps I've taken to become less eco-damaging.

item.title: Sinn
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: Der Sinn des Lebens. Schlaflose Nächte und eine neue Idee.

item.title: Nouns and Verbs
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description:
In our beloved western societies we are very much goal oriented. Things are achieved mostly by communicating goals and commandments, together with a demand of fulfillment.

Since goal-orientation is everywhere it can be a challenge to even notice that it is constantly going on, and differentiate “normal” advice with advice that is actually helpful.

item.title: Germany's Nuclear Peace Plan
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: In a time when the whole world is under economic pressure due to COVID-19, the German government discusses spending billions on purchasing and maintaining 30 new nuclear flight jets (F18F).

item.title: Identity and Attention
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: Identity can be a small thing. I could identify with my home country, my line of work, my monthly salary or my family name. It could be my hometown, the brand of clothes I wear or a degree I achieved. Actually, identity can be a big thing. If that is so, how can the identity be picked intelligently and how can that choice be undermined by mere attention?

item.title: Survival and Living
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: Which differences can we find between survival and living in today's world? Which of the two holds that sweet sweet satisfaction we're longing for? The meaning we attach to “survival” needs to be refreshed, as in today's world we have everything we need, while life can seem dull and repetitive at times.

item.title: Windows 10 vs Ubuntu 18
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: As of this month, Windows is still the dominating desktop / laptop OS globally with 88% market share. Windows for me - and for most users, has always been the default. However, coming back from a Linux environment I realized this: Windows is not that great of an OS.

item.title: Adults through childrens eyes
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: Adults in many ways do have superpowers in the eyes of a child. They have authority. They are allowed to do many of the things a child cannot do: eat candy whenever they want, stay up late, drive cars, and schedule their days at their own leisure. Despite these superpowers, they didn't seem super to me as a child. Observing adults faszinated and irritated me, as I'm recalling in this blogpost.

item.title: Making Emacs recognize its physical location
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: My emacs now behaves differently when I'm at home! This enables me to have my private configuration loaded automatically when needed, while I have all my work-settings enabled otherwise.

item.title: The Process of Self-Revelation
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: Today, I gobbled down two chicken-halves and some mashed potatoes. That was a lot. The other time I was still hungry after a single half, and this time around I was stressing out over barely finishing the meal. I needed to sit down for a bit. I picked a sunny spot. Me being me I took some time to meditate and suddenly I had an epiphany: “We are afraid of ourselves, and that is what life is.". Believe me, this was not the chicken talk, but I had finally figured something out. Let me elaborate…

item.title: Organizing Music
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: I finally found a half-way decent, quick and simple system to organize my music.

item.title: Religion: Problems and Strenghts
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: Yesterday, a couple cute Mormon missionaries came over to me and chatted me up. I estimated the three of them to be roughly my age, probably a couple years younger, around 22 to 23. It was a beautiful, sunny Saturday and I incidentally was sitting on a bench near a church. Later they told me they are specifically roaming these areas to do their work. They started out the conversation talking about their strong belief in god, how they talk to him, and how he would answer them their questions. They proceeded asking me what questions I had for god. I didn't have one and couldn't even come up with one, but I was interested in chatting with them, so I invited them to sit down with me.

item.title: Tinder Manifesto
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description:
Manifesto: noun. A public declaration of policy and aims, especially one issued before an election by a political party or candidate.

Tinder could get dirty. Tinder could get tedious. I wrote down my original aims when I started using tinder here, before everything falls into chaos later. Much like with other manifestos ;)

item.title: What do we know about who we want to be?
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: It is pretty important for each of us to be the person we want to be. For survival, for society, for integrity. But what do we know then about who we want to be?

item.title: The three most important skills to have as a young adult
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description:
TL;DR:

  • The skill to change your habits, so you could start trying new ones (better or worse than your current ones) to begin with.
  • The skill to build the desire of trying things truly out of your comfort zone, so you could expand your horizon and thereby change more of your habits.
  • The skill of writing, so you could articulate what it is that you want. Also writing can be a great tool for changing your habits.

item.title: Monitoring & Ansible, Part I: NRPE daemon setup
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: Monitoring servers using icinga usually requires a small setup on the monitored server. From the different choices of agents, the nrpe daemon ontop of xinetd is easy enough to set up, while it can provide any kind of information that is available on the monitored server locally. To automate this setup task and as a learning exercise I wrote up an Ansible playbook, which I describe here. The linux world is big, so you might come here asking: “Why the hell do you use xinetd and nrpe for monitoring?

item.title: Wie stehst Du im Leben?
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: Wie stehst du im Leben? Ein einfaches Beobachten der Körperhaltung kann einem schon buchstäblich zeigen wie man im Leben steht. Es ist eine Art Haltungs-Check. Jeder liest Körperhaltung - zumindest unbewusst, meine Beobachtung dazu teile ich hier.

item.title: Procmail learns html
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: Recently I wrote a procmail filter which filters mail for a ticketing system (request-tracker). It filters mails which addresses the ticketing system in Cc as well as mails with attachments bigger than 10 MB. I went through quite a learning curve while writing this filter so I'd like to share it here.

item.title: About me
item.author: felix.brilej@googlemail.com (Felix Brilej)
item.description: I like IT among many other things, I like free software. I find great joy in designing and creating IT systems that work well. Tech is not my only passion. I'm also interested in philosophy and mindfulness.
